I posted a thread just today in gameplay with practice test results that show why ADCs have made assassins obsolete. 
Against the practice dummy Jinx will do 1850 DPS per second, or 3700 damage in 2 seconds. Talon takes 2 seconds to do 2700 damage with his Q/W/AA burst combo, but that damage only full registers after an additional 2 seconds for the bleed damage to fully proc. Talon will have nothing left at that point but slow and relatively weak auto attacks, whereas Jinx still gets to keep doing 1850 damage per second until the teamfight is over. If you were to factor in that Talon continues to auto attack the target during the 2 seconds bleed period, he'll do even less damage overall than Jinx. 

Jinx also will probably have ample lifesteal, meaning that it's entirely possible (and I've had this happen to me) for the Jinx to survive your burst purely off the lifesteal she's getting during the 2 seconds it takes for your combo to execute and the 2 seconds it takes for your bleed to fully proc. You'll die and she'll be back to full health soon like nothing happened.

Even if talon uses the second half of his R damage after gapclosing with stealth, he'll only do about 3000 damage in about 1 second (actually, the damage will be significantly less because the 3000 damage figure requires an additional 2 seconds for the bleed damage to fully proc). This number just assumes that if you only have enough time to get 1 seconds of burst off before being peeled, that's how much damage you'll at least get off, assuming the target doesn't heal or shield in the meantime.

So this is an extremely marginal window of usefulness. Only in this very specific circumstance can you do something Jinx can't. You can do more damage in one second than she can, but only if you use your ultimate, and it often won't be enough to kill a lifestealing ADC in a teamfighting context anyway. So you end up asking yourself, why bother going through all the hassle of playing Talon if that's the only thing I gain? Yeah I can roam around, but that doesn't do me any good once the teamfighting phase of the game starts and I am unlikely to kill anyone important worth sacrificing myself for. Do I really want to do more damage in one second that I'm willing to risk not getting the kill at all due to all the shields, heals, lifesteal, statis effects, CC, etc ? I may as well just play a secondary ADC, secure my kills, and be a lot more useful to the entire team with sustained assassin level damage. 

Conclusion: A typical itemized ADC will assassinate better than the purest assassin champion in the game.

Reason 1: Delayed burst on an assassin was a stupid idea from the start. That's why Leblanc got reverted. You cease to have an assassin be an assassin when you put in delayed burst. Talon was still one of the most bursty of the reworked assassins, but after they toned down his numbers and nerfed lethality the delays he does have become dealbreakers. 

Reason 2: ADCs get their items too fast. Laning phase ends 10 minutes earlier than it use to. That window of usefulness where roaming assassins had a chance to influence the map is small and means very little towards influencing the outcome of the game in most elos. That's why mages and assassins all have taken a backseat, and toplane just becomes a farming lane for teamfighting tanks. And midlane just becomes a farming lane for teamfight mages. With some roaming thrown in aimed at getting bot lane fed.

THEN: If I played a mage in the past you would usually get knocked out pretty fast by adc, but if I could land a good combo they were either dead or low and easy pickings for my team.  If I survived I would probably be lower health and back or risk being picked off easy.   If the ADC survived they were in teh same situation.

NOW:  A mage still gets knocked out pretty fast, but now so are tanks.  Now I still get half a chance to land a good combo, but half the time their 1 or 2 initial shots get them back enough life the survive my burst, if the combo is perfect you might off them. If the ADC survives they just shoot a minion or two, are back up to full and can continue team fighting or pushing.  ADCs pretty much never have to back unless they are buying items.

The safety nets are too big for ADCs.  They get the massive damage, but they should not get all the sustain and utility to go with it.
